Detailed Description

Input stream tokenizer.

Author:
Marc Parizeau, Laboratoire de vision et systèmes numériques, Université Laval

This class is for tokenizing an input stream. Tokens are either strings of characters seperated by white space, or special single-characters. By default, there are no special single-character tokens, and white space characters are spaces, tabs, cariage returns, and line-feeds. But these can be changed using method Tokenizer::setDelimiters. For instance, if "a" and "d" are single character tokens, then string "abcd" will be tokenized in "a"+"bc" + "d".

By default, the tokenizer uses an internal read buffer to accelerate the parse of the stream (up to 4x). The buffer size can be specified in the object constructor (default=1024) or set by method Tokenizer::setBufferSize. A buffer size of 0 actually disactivate the use of the internal buffer.

Definition at line 58 of file Tokenizer.hpp.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Tokenizer::Tokenizer ( unsigned int  inBufSize = 1024  ) 

Construct a default tokenizer with no input stream.

The internal read buffer size can be set with argument inBufSize (default=1024). This buffer can also be disactivated by setting this argument to 0. The internal read buffer can greatly accelerate the parse of the stream. A size between 512 and 1024 appears to give good results in most circumstances.

Attention:
It should be noted that the use of such a buffer implies that the stream must be fully parsed by this tokenizer, because there is no way to put it's content back into the stream.

Definition at line 50 of file Tokenizer.cpp.

00053     setDelimiters(" \t\n\r", "");
00054     setBufferSize(inBufSize);

The internal read buffer size can be set with argument inBufSize (default=1024). This buffer can also be disactivated by setting this argument to 0. The internal read buffer can greatly accelerate the parse of the stream. A size between 512 and 1024 appears to give the best results in most circumstances.

Attention:
It should be noted that the use of such a buffer implies that the stream must be fully parsed by this tokenizer, because there is no way to put it's content back into the stream.

Member Function Documentation

bool Tokenizer::getNextToken ( string &  outToken  ) 

Parse next token of default input stream.

Returns:
True if a valid token was found, false otherwise.

This method finds the next token in the default input stream, after removing any leading white space. The token is returned through argument outToken. An empty token (string) means that end of stream was reached.

00094 {
00095     PACC_AssertM(mStream, "undefined input stream!");
00096     if(!mTokens.empty()) {
00097         // use putback tokens if available
00098         outToken = mTokens.top();
00099         mTokens.pop();
00100     } else if(mBufSize == 0) {
00101         // DO NOT use the input read buffer
00102         register unsigned char lChar;
00103         // get rid of leading white space
00104         do {
00105             lChar = mStream->get();
00106             if(mStream->eof()) {
00107                 outToken.resize(0);
00108                 return false;
00109             }
00110             if(lChar == '\n') ++mLine;
00111         } while(mDelimiters[lChar] == eWhiteSpace);
00112         outToken = lChar;
00113         // append until next white space or single char token
00114         char lOutBuffer[100];
00115         while(mDelimiters[lChar] == 0 && !mStream->eof()) {
00116             unsigned lOutCount = 0;
00117             while(lOutCount < sizeof(lOutBuffer)) {
00118                 lChar = mStream->get();
00119                 if(mStream->eof()) break;
00120                 if(mDelimiters[lChar] != 0) {
00121                     // put character back into stream
00122                     mStream->putback(lChar);
00123                     break;
00124                 }
00125                 lOutBuffer[lOutCount++] = lChar;
00126                 // check for end-of-line counter
00127                 if(lChar == '\n') ++mLine;
00128             }
00129             outToken.append(lOutBuffer, lOutCount);
00130         }
00131     } else {
00132         // otherwise, use the input read buffer
00133         register unsigned char lChar;
00134         // get rid of leading white space
00135         do {
00136             if(mBufCount == 0 && fillBuffer() == 0) {
00137                 outToken.resize(0);
00138                 return false;
00139             }
00140             lChar = *(mBufPtr++); --mBufCount;
00141             if(lChar == '\n') ++mLine;
00142         } while(mDelimiters[lChar] == eWhiteSpace);
00143         outToken = lChar;
00144         // append until next white space or single char token
00145         char lOutBuffer[100];
00146         while(mDelimiters[lChar] == 0 && mBufPtr != mBuffer) {
00147             unsigned lOutCount = 0;
00148             while(lOutCount < sizeof(lOutBuffer)) {
00149                 if(mBufCount == 0 && fillBuffer() == 0) break;
00150                 lChar = *(mBufPtr++); --mBufCount;
00151                 if(mDelimiters[lChar] != 0) {
00152                     // put character back into buffer
00153                     --mBufPtr; ++mBufCount;
00154                     break;
00155                 }
00156                 lOutBuffer[lOutCount++] = lChar;
00157                 // check for end-of-line counter
00158                 if(lChar == '\n') ++mLine;
00159             }
00160             outToken.append(lOutBuffer, lOutCount);
00161         }
00162     }
00163     return !outToken.empty();
00164 }

string Tokenizer::getNextToken ( void   ) 

Parse next token of default input stream.

Returns:
String of next token found.

This method finds the next token in the default input stream, after removing any leading white space. An empty token (string) means that end of stream was reached.

Attention:
This method is deprecated.

Definition at line 81 of file Tokenizer.cpp.

int Tokenizer::peekNextChar ( void   ) 

Return the next character from the default input stream.

Returns:
-1 if end-of-stream.

This method returns the next character without removing it from the input stream.

00193     else if(mBufSize == 0) return mStream->peek();
00194     else {
00195         // otherwise, use buffer
00196         if(mBufCount == 0 && fillBuffer() == 0) return -1;
00197         return *mBufPtr;

void Tokenizer::putbackToken ( const string &  inToken  ) 

Put back token inToken.

This method uses a stack to store tokens that will be returned by Tokenizer::getNextToken in LIFO order.

Attention:
Any number of tokens can be put back, but take note that these WILL NOT be parsed again, if the user decides to change delimiters.

Definition at line 206 of file Tokenizer.cpp.

00207 {
00208     PACC_AssertM(!inToken.empty(), "cannot put back an empty string!");
00209     mTokens.push(inToken);
00210 }

void Tokenizer::setBufferSize ( unsigned int  inSize  ) 

Set the size of the internal read buffer to size inSize.

The minimum buffer size is set to 10. A smaller buffer size will disable the use of the internal read buffer.

Attention:
This method should be called prior to the first call of method Tokenizer::getNextToken, because it is an error to resize a buffer that is not empty. Method Tokenizer::setStream should be called explicitely to flush the buffer .

Definition at line 217 of file Tokenizer.cpp.

00218 {
00219     delete[] mBuffer;
00220     if(inSize < 10) inSize = 0; 
00221     if(inSize > 0) mBuffer = new char[inSize];
00222     else mBuffer = 0;
00223     mBufSize = inSize;
00224     mBufCount = 0;
00225 }

void Tokenizer::setDelimiters ( const string &  inWhiteSpace,
const string &  inSingleCharTokens 
)

Set the white space delimiters to the characters of inWhiteSpace, and the single character delimiters to those of inToken.

The white space and single character delimiters are set to the characters contained in strings inWhiteSpace and inSingleCharTokens, respectively. The white space characters delimit tokens but are not tokens themselves. Single character tokens are tokens that delimit other tokens.

Definition at line 230 of file Tokenizer.cpp.

00231 {
00232     memset(mDelimiters, 0, sizeof(mDelimiters));
00233     for(string::const_iterator i = inWhiteSpace.begin(); i != inWhiteSpace.end(); ++i) {
00234         mDelimiters[(unsigned)*i] = eWhiteSpace;
00235     }
00236     for(string::const_iterator i = inSingleCharTokens.begin(); i != inSingleCharTokens.end(); ++i) {
00237         PACC_AssertM(mDelimiters[(unsigned)*i] == 0, "a delimiter cannot be both white space and single char token!");
00238         mDelimiters[(unsigned)*i] = eSingleChar;
00239     }
00240 }

void Tokenizer::setStream ( istream &  inStream  ) 

Set the input stream to inStream.

This method sets a new stream to be tokenized. It also flushes the internal read buffer.
